Lots of sad news including the death of my good friend K. I. Nieh,
sarved 14 years as Assistant Operations Manager. Also the wife of E.C.Heu,
my #1 Chinese assistant in Shanghai had been murdered by the Japs.

Saddest of all was a rumor that one of our whole family's
closest friends-M.Y. Tang had been shot for treason. He was one of T. V.
Soong's most trusted associates, and as President of the Bank of Canton (Hong
refused to leave Hong Kong when Bond offered to, fly him out, because he
didn't want to leave his Bank or the pople who worked there.

the bank open,

then, but there is no doubt whatever in my mind but that M. Y. Tong was

That tragedy reminded me that only in the
British Inpire and the United States is a man sure of that elemental right of
trial by juryl
Certainly that is one of the things for which we are fighting!

We climbed up then and headed straight for Calcutta,
which we reached without incident just an the sun was setting.
Stayed on in Calcutta living the life of Riley at the Sharp's
the 25th,
when as a result of a conference with the Army it became
evident that Bond would have to stay on for at least another week, and so
I determined to leave as soon as possible.
That was the beginning of a
strenuous trip home.
I left viaATC for New Delhi, expecting to arrive there
at midnight.
Inatead we arrived at 5 AM, with very little sleep on the air-
plane--those
bucket seats are about us confortable as the pers at the Bolton
Baptist Church (as I rarember them from several years ago.)
Was scheduled to leave New Delhi at 11:45 PM on Friday the 26th,
